item.title: Contact
item.description:
We constantly seek possible collaborations regarding interesting projects, novel methods, data, and publications in spatial freshwater biodiversity science and beyond. Please do not hesitate to contact us to discuss further details.

Join the group?

Interested in joining the group? We are looking for motivated candidates across the Master, PhD and Postdoc levels. If you are interested please drop us a line indicating your research interests & plans and we can discuss how to move things further and possibly seek for funding opportunities.

We will have two PhD student positions opening soon with an envisaged start in 2020 - please check back later for details.


We use, beside R, largely open-source (command-line) GIS tools within the Linux environment that facilitate handling and analyzing large datasets (see also some of the tools here). We consider a good understanding, or alternatively, a great motivation to learn such tools & techniques as a prerequisite to join the group.

item.title: Data & Code
item.description:
Here is a collection of code and tutorials for spatial analyses in freshwater ecosystems, and we will be gradually adding more:

  • Create freshwater-specific environmental variables
  • How to move point records to a stream network and extract the values
  • A quick guide of using open-source GIS tools using the Linux command-line
  • Bayesian hierarchical species distribution models

If you have any questions or noticed any bugs in the code please drop us a line.

Some more useful tools and websites:

  • Geocomputation with R by Robin Lovelace, Jakub Nowosad, Jannes Muenchow
  • Spatial Data Science with R by Robert J. Hijmans
  • Species distribution modeling in R using the dismo R-package (maintained by Robert J. Hijmans, Steven Phillips, John Leathwick and Jane Elith)
  • Species’ Distribution Modeling for Conservation Educators and Practitioners by Richard G. Pearson
  • Spatial-Ecology providing training in open-source software for geospatial data processing
  • Spatial Modeling on Stream Networks (SSN) by Jay Ver Hoef and Erin Peterson
  • openSTARS: the open-source version for preparing the data for the SSN-package by Mira Kattwinkel

item.title: Global freshwater biodiversity, biogeography & conservation (GLOWABIO)
item.description:
Global biodiversity is declining across ecosystems, and freshwater organisms and habitats are among the most threatened. While finding appropriate countermeasures, a key challenge is first to gain a comprehensive picture of the current status of freshwater biodiversity. Compared to the terrestrial and marine realms, freshwater biodiversity remains understudied in terms of its ecological significance and distinctiveness, resulting in a lack of effective conservation at regional to global scales.

The Leibniz-Junior Research Group aims to fill this gap by applying cutting-edge global geospatial analyses focusing on: (i) a new habitat type delineation using a newly developed, global hydrography at very high spatial resolution (90m); (ii) state-of-the-art Bayesian models to map freshwater biodiversity based on an extensive global dataset compiled over the past years on the occurrence of aquatic insects, the most diverse freshwater animal group; and (iii) applying novel systematic conservation network analyses to highlight potential gaps in the protection of underrepresented habitat types and taxa across national boundaries. The combined application of these core elements at the global scale, yet at high spatial resolution, will allow ground-breaking, standardised and comparative analyses in spatial freshwater biodiversity science. Importantly, uncertainties inherent in the data and analyses will be quantified to ensure transparency and robustness of the results.

Key aspects in terms of feasibility and an open science strategy are: (i) all required data are already available, (ii) all analyses will be performed by using open-source geospatial tools, and (iii) all data layers and codes will be stored in public repositories to enable follow-up analyses by others. The project will promote national and international synergies, and inform global initiatives such as IPBES, Future Earth, and Freshwater-BON, to improve our understanding of the current status of freshwater biodiversity.


The Leibniz-Junior Research Group is co-funded by the Leibniz-Institute of Freshwater Ecology and Inland Fisheries in Berlin, Germany.

item.title: Research
item.description:
We are currently focusing on several topics:

  • Creating novel high-resolution freshwater ecoregions
  • Analyzing spatial patterns in global freshwater biodiversity
  • Spatial conservation planning given habitat and biodiversity features
  • Scale-dependencies in freshwater species distribution models
  • Niche evolution of Tibetan-Himalayan Rhyacophilidae (Trichoptera)
  • Alliance for Freshwater Life
